definitions.definition: to put powder, lipstick, etc. on your/somebodyâ€™s face to make it more attractive or to prepare for an appearance in the theatre, on television, etc.

examples.text: Women make up 56 per cent of the student numbers.
The course is made up of 12 two-hour sessions.

definitions.definition: to put something together from several different things
to invent a story, etc., especially in order to trick or entertain somebody

examples.text: He made up some excuse about his daughter being sick.
I told the kids a story, making it up as I went along.

definitions.definition: to complete a number or an amount required

examples.text: We need one more person to make up a team.

definitions.definition: to replace something that has been lost; to compensate for something

examples.text: Can I leave early this afternoon and make up the time tomorrow?

definitions.definition: to prepare a medicine by mixing different things together
to prepare a bed for use; to create a temporary bed

examples.text: We made up the bed in the spare room.
They made up a bed for me on the sofa.

definitions.definition: to clean a hotel room and make the bed

examples.text: The maid asked if she could make up the room.
They had forgotten to make up the room.

definitions.definition: to end an argument with somebody and become friends again

examples.text: Why don't you two **kiss and make up**?
Has he made it up with her yet?
Have they made it up yet?
